Review title: Thrills beyond belief and spectacular story-telling and an unforgettable experience.
Review_body: Psycho. Directed by Alfred Hitchcock. Based on the novel by Robert Bloch. Starring Anthony Perkins, Vera Miles, and John Gavin. Rated R with a running time of 109 minutes. Given an 8.6/10 on IMDb.com and 97% Fresh on Rottentomatoes.com "A thirty-something secretary steals $40,000 from her employer's client, and subsequently encounters a young motel proprietor too long under the domination of his mother.""Bates Motel" the modern prequel series to Psycho has left me absolutely intrigued. I had heard of Hitchcock's masterpiece but I had never actually seen and with myself being an immense film addict, how could I have possibly missed such a remarkable gem? I'd known the entire plot. Every twist turn and stab. I honestly thought I was capable of understanding exactly what I was going to get here, but boy was I wrong. Thrills beyond belief and spectacular story-telling. Alfred Hitchcock is an absolute cinematic genius. Choosing to keep the film in black and white, killing off his protagonist halfway through the film, pushing and pulling the audience in every direction he wants them to be in. His camera angles and overall eye for entertainment has yet to be matched by any modern filmmaker. This man and this film are not only responsible for revolutionizing the horror genre, but showing the world the validity of it. Expect to be mesmerized by this piece.We are given Anthony Perkins, who doesn't just play the role of Norman Bates, but he becomes him. The character is embodied with such power and perfection that seeing Perkins in any role but this terrifies me beyond belief. Vera Miles and John Gavin team up as Lila Crane and Sam Loomis. Together they weave a team of compassionate and caring people, searching for answers in a mind bending mystery. Miles performs beautifully. She's innocent and loving and just wants to find her sister, but there's this air to her that strikes me, making me wonder how complex Lila is capable of being. If you're able to portray a character to the point that a viewer wishes to know more about that character, I give you the utmost respect. John Gavin as Sam Loomis bored me at the start but soon he became ideal. Loomis and Bates are compared and contrasted in an ironically obvious but eye-opening light. They are both extremely handsome men but Loomis is intimidating, strong, manly. Whereas, Norman Bates is a shy, childish, coward. The scenes where the two actors battle in out in conversation kept me on the edge of my seat. Once again, I have to add that Anthony Perkins is a genius and every motion, reaction, and word that comes from him in this film delivers an unforgettable experience.My only complaint worth noting is the scene in which the psychologist explains Norman and His Mother to the audience. It's a bit drawn out and the psychologist is delivering shocking and heartbreaking information but there seems to be little reaction from him or anyone in the room. Rather than telling me what happened, I'd have rather seen it for myself, Something that's easy to do in film. But this scene is necessary and it won't take a single thing away from this movie.Overall, Psycho is one of the greatest films I've ever seen. It's a horrifying thrill-ride with a twist that no one will ever see coming and what it did for the movie world will never be forgotten. Alfred Hitchcock toys with our wildest emotions and fears and spawns a true work of art. I'll have to ask my mother what she thought of the film because, well, mother knows best. But, I'd say that if you decide that Bates Motel has No Vacany's for you, well Norman and I will both in form you that we have 12 Vacancy's and all 12 should be filled by you.

Review title: Horror Fans Who Consider themselves 'Horror Fans' and haven't seen this movie shouldn't consider themselves horror fans.
Review_body: Psycho is a film that marks its place in movie history. From beginning to end, you are focused, listening to every word they say. But when stuff goes down, you are hiding behind your blanket, trying to protect yourself from what you're about to see. Yeah, it's from the 1960's, but this isn't like a 1960's horror movie. The film is thrilling and violent, but most of all, it's entertaining from beginning to end. With a killer soundtrack, it's no wonder you jump out of your seat when something surprising happens. And, yes. The twist ending is the father of twist endings. It's great. Long story short, see this movie. I recommend it to everyone reading this, and everyone not reading this, still see the movie. It's really good.10/10

Being a fan of horror films, I realised that I hadn't actually watched one of the biggest horror films that EVER existed - Psycho. I was really reluctant to watch it because it's an old film and I'm so accustomed to all of the new horror films that are appearing all over our screens...but I finally purchased the DVD and sat down with a big bowl of popcorn and galaxy chocolate to watch it. I have to say, taking everything into account, it is my favourite horror film of ALL time. Why? Not just because it was in black and white and is a classic...but because it's so simple and easy to follow and there's no gimmicks. The story is believable and haunting and so refreshing to watch at a time when the world is so advanced and modern with technology being capable of anything. But this film had NO special effects; it was art in its purest form and I adored the film! Alfred Hitchcock is a genius in portraying a really sinister plot in such a clever, straightforward way and it really hones in what it really takes to make a film truly compelling. I felt it was such an honour to watch Anthony Perkins on screen portray such an intriguing character in such a successful way. He really captured the essence of the character and made the film a true gem. I'm not going to give away any spoilers but I have to say that Psycho is the best horror film ever made and the storyline is beautiful in its simplicity and shock factor. It will keep you on the edge of your seat and the ending is just.....wow.

This had to be Alfred Hitchcock's best movie. In fact, it was my favorite Alfred Hitchcock movie. This movie was perfectly executed by Hitchcock. The acting was unbelievably tremendous. Each actor did an excellent job(especially Anthony Perkins and Janet Leigh). The screenplay was great and the writing was tremendous. It's a movie about a woman(Leigh) who is out driving on a rainy night(after stealing a lot of money) and she stops at a motel where the owner has a mother, but is very lonely and befriends her. When she takes a shower, the figure of an old lady walks in and stabs her to death in the shower(this is remembered as the famous "shower scene"). This was excellent and I give it a perfect 10 out of 10.

What else can one write about a film that has been expounded by numerous film scholars? We all know about the famous shower scene, don't we? But there's so much more to "Psycho" than that. It works well as a psychological thriller but if one understands the psyche of "Psycho" it works remarkably as a horror movie (notwithstanding that we are immune to on-screen gore now).There is a reason why director is considered to be the most important person in a movie. We have heard about the legend of Hitchcok - the great director. The same story could have been rendered to a derivative b-movie by an average director but Hitchcock took it to unforeseen greatness. He made a great use of Robert Blotch's book. Where else would you see a mainstream suspense-horror film put on the highest pedestal of cinema? There's no emptiness in a Hitchcock film. Every scene has a purpose and underlying meaning. There could be a meta-movie on the relationship between two sisters, who we never see together on screen for the obvious reason. We get a hint of their possibly strained relationship at the end. But it's done very offhandedly, very skilfully by the master. The possibilities of analyses are endless.

I was first introduced to Alfred Hitchcock when I was very young, however, it was not until now that I knew what a monumental influence he had on film. In my college film class we had the chance to view Psycho and i have to admit at first, i was not extremely excited about it. However, I was hooked in the first five minutes of the film and I couldn't keep my eyes off the screen. I love psychological thrillers that make you wonder and think "outside the box" and i think this was one of the best i have ever seen. I think that Alfred's choices for the movie, (director, characters, etc.) were great. I thought all the characters did a fabulous job. The story line and plot were very creative too. I felt like i was being surprised every five minutes. I also like that this is an old black and white film. I don't think that it would have had the same impact on me if it was a modern story in color. It is definitely a classic!

Alfred Hitchcock is so much more than a film director. He is the prototype for the making of suspense thrillers, an exemplar of genius filmmaking, and the innovator of true terror. Hitchcock changed film forever when he released his box office record breaking phenomena Psycho. With an explosive cast starring Anthony Perkins, Vera Miles and Janet Leigh, Psycho is a work of cinematic art. Said to have been the very first slasher film Psycho had both a cinematic and a social influence. Hitchcock opens the film with what many believe to be one of the best opening credit sequences of all time. He splits the words as they come across the screen alluding to what we are going to find out later about Mr. Bates. The story starts with us meeting Marion Crane (played by the beautiful Vera Miles). Hitchcock portrays Marion in a way that regardless of the crime she may be committing the audience cannot help but to root for her. Even though we watch her commit this crime Hitchcock paints it in a way that we do feel like she is justified. She steals the money from a man that does not appear to deserve it and her motive for taking the money is love. Hitchcock even alludes that she was going to return the money but she is murdered before she has the chance to. Which is why the stabbing in the shower scene is so horrifying and to this day seen as one of the most influential scenes in film history. Audiences during this time were not used to their protagonist dying suddenly. This scene was influential in the sense that it influenced society the same way films like Jaws and The Blair Witch Project did. The shower scene made something that normally would not be associated as scary terrifying. After Psycho's release people were afraid to shower showing the influence Hitchcock had even outside the theater. Anthony Perkins gives a stunning performance of Norman Bates, a severely troubled man who appears to live alone with his mother. After our protagonist is murdered, the audience has no choice but to sympathize and find a new one. This is so meticulously done by Hitchcock it is barley even noticed. We start to root for Norman because we do not yet know he is the murderer but associate him as a dedicated son. We watch him cover up the countless number of startling murders his mother commits until we find out that he is actually playing the role of his mother in one of the biggest plot twists of all time. Psycho has indisputably become one of the most renowned films in history. It has influenced an entire genre and has become the blueprint of great horror films. To this day it is seen as frightening for first time viewers and will continue to inspire filmmaker's worldwide.

Psycho was a very interesting and startling film. The Director used non diegetic sound during the shower scene to add suspense, which was brilliant, because the audience got to experience a thrill. The Director used the name " Bates Motel" to warn the audience that something is wrong about this certain Motel. The Director wanted to use a name that sticks out and will be remembered. Through out the whole film the Director uses clues that lead up to the most startling part of the film. The Director uses an Aerial shot when Norman Bates carries his mother out of the room to let the audience know something intriguing is going to happen. Near the very end of the movie the audience gets the shock of their lives, because when the detective went down to the cellar there was a chair in the middle of the room. When the detective turns the chair around he and the audience discover a Skeleton sitting in the chair! The Skeleton was Norman Bate's dead mother. Norman killed his mother and kept her Skeleton! At the very end of the film the audience soon discovers Norman Bates has a mental disability and his brain took the form of his mother's personality.

The angles and the way he let's the camera, lead or suggest to the viewer, the next scene,is alone, among the best direction of any movie. I believe one will get a different understanding of this film, and a greater appreciation of the director.

Like many Hitchcock films, Psycho plays upon the theme of an emotional mood or effect. Much like Hitchcock's The Birds, the eerie silences create tension and suspense leaving the viewers in anticipation of what might be coming next. Hitchcock further immerses the viewer into a state of suspense with clever editing that accentuates the character's perspective and puts the viewer in the place of the characters on screen.Psycho follows the story of Marion Crane (Janet Leigh) and the unfortunate events that follow her meeting of Norman Bates (Anthony Perkins). Marion Crane works a normal day job in Phoenix, Arizona but is unhappy in her romance with the Sam Loomis (John Gavin). Sam is facing a great deal of debt and doesn't have the financial means to get married. On one normal day at the office, Marion is asked to make a $40,000 cash deposit on her way home from work. Marion decides to pack her suitcase and take the money in hopes that this will allow her and Sam to run away together.Once on the road, a heavy rainstorm forces Marion to lose her way on the road. She decides to stop at an isolated hotel off the road. Marion checks into the Bates Motel and meets Norman Bates. Norman is a seemingly nice young man who tends to the hotel and his ailing mother who lives in the house just behind the motel. Marion and Norman have a meal together and after hearing Norman's tale and thinking about her own decisions, Marion decides she will return to Phoenix with the money in the morning.Unfortunately, while Marion is taking a shower a shadowy figure enters the bathroom and stabs her to death. Norman runs to the room and discovers Marion's lifeless body lying on the floor. He collects her belongings and with the body, loads them in the trunk of her car and disposes of the vehicle in a local pond. Weeks later, Lila Crane (Vera Miles), Marion's sister, arrives to speak with Sam to determine whether he knows the whereabouts of Marion. The two are approached by Private Investigator Milton Arbogast (Martin Balsam) who has been hired to return the money to Marion's employer.Milton Arbogast is convinced that Sam and Lila are unaware of Marion's location and he decides to start checking on all the roadside motels to determine if she stopped anywhere. Milton Arbogast finds his way to the Bates Motel where he meets Norman Bates. After a tense conversation, Milton discovers that Marion had indeed stayed at the motel. He finds a pay phone to let Sam and Lila know that he will be checking in with them, but that he had to check out the hotel again. Milton Arbogast decides to check out the home above the Bates Motel to speak to Norman's mother. As he walks up the staircase, a woman comes out of a room and murders him.Sam and Lila go to search for the missing Arbogast and arrive at the Bates Motel. They meet Norman and create a ruse for Sam to occupy Norman, while Lila goes to the house to look for Arbogast. Norman figures out what's going on and knocks out Sam. Meanwhile, Lila searches the house and finds nothing. As she hears Norman entering the house, she hides in the basement. In the basement, she finds the corpse of what appears to be Mrs. Bates. As she screams, we see Norman wearing his mother's clothes coming at her with a knife. Sam arrives just in time to stop Norman. The police take Norman into custody, where we find out Norman's mother personality has taken over his mind.Psycho is an excellent film that will keep the viewer on the edge of their seats. The audience will delve into madness with Norman and make you forever cautious of stopping by a roadside motel.

I think that Hitchcock's Psycho has a great plot, but it does not quite fit the genre it is categorized as. The plot has a lot of elements that make it great, such as the many surprises it contains that keeps the viewer intrigued. The film makes us believe that one thing is happening when it is really another that is completely different. Norman is a good example of these surprises as we learn more about his character. Norman is a very dynamic character; in the beginning of the film the viewer would see him as a poor hotel keeper trying to make a living. As the film progresses the viewer can start to see the weird things Norman does and they start to question his character until the end when they realize what is actually going on. Marion's character is also a great example of how the plot is able to keep the viewers interested with its many surprises. Viewers would see her as an innocent worker at the beginning of the film and then she takes the money and makes a run for it surprising the viewers.
Despite Psycho having a great plot I don't believe it should be categorized as a horror film. During the whole movie I never found anything to be particularly scary. The film did have a creepiness to it, but nothing made me feel frightened. The scene I feel is supposed to be the most terrifying is when Marion is killed in the shower, but I didn't find it scary and thins could just be because of the horror movies I have grown up with. Another scene that I thought was supposed to be terrifying is the scene at the end when Norman is staring into the camera. To me this scene was just creepy but I'm sure when the movie came out people probably thought that it was almost like he was in the room with them so it would have been more scary. There were no jump scares and not really any blood or gory. This may have been a great horror movie when it first came out but compared to today's horror movies this film is not a horror movie.

"Psycho" is the ultimate suspense film. The plot is superbly developed and exhilaratingly full of psychological manipulation. It is without any hum-our - voluntary or involuntary - whatsoever, but this only adds to the clarity and starkness of the story, and above all of the images. They stick to your retina and stay lodged in your brain for ever - resemblant of "Potemkin" - but without the stills effect. And to round it off, the real mark of excellence: a brilliant ending. I remember coming out of the movie theater after seeing "Psycho" for the first time, at the age of 16. I was devastated. Drained. I instinctively knew there was something deeply truthful in this film. Just like "The Silence of the Lambs". Disturbing - but absolutely credible. Which - of course - would not have been possible without good actors. So turn off the lights, shut out the world around you, and I can guarantee you will be sucked into this "flick".

Review title: Easily the greatest Slasher film ever
Review_body: I'll start off by naming a few slasher films worth mentioning. Silence of the Lambs, A Nightmare on Elm Srt., Friday the 13th, Halloween, The Texas Chainsaw Massacre. Need I name more? All of these, stressing ALL of them, are great genre defining motion pictures. BUT, they are not THE genre defining slasher motion picture. That title goes only to Psycho. Nobody else would have dared to have a Serial Killer in drag killing off a naked woman showering before this point.However, influence alone does not make a movie good. Look at the other aspects of the movie. So many of today's horror films focus around so much gore and violence that there's such an uneven mix of gore, emotion, acting, properly introducing characters, etc. Everything in Psycho is just right. Alfred Hitchcock's works are just so great at only using so much of certain things. Everything is well balanced. You meet the characters, you feel sympathetic for the characters. You get to love them before the violence starts. That's what makes this film so good.

Review title: Scariest and best movie i've ever seen
Review_body: I was not even a gleam in my father's eye when this movie was made, and yet this movie is as scary now as I'm sure it was then.  "Scary" movies these days generally do not scare me at all.  Alfred Hitchcock's movies have always had an uncanny ability to scare the wits out of me.  Particular Vertigo and this movie.  The Birds was scary also, but not as disturbing as these.  Now, about this review.  I had never seen this before and on a boring Saturday evening I decided to go buy this dvd from the local store. So, I got it and watched it that night.  I watched it with the lights out, my surround system cranked, and on the edge of my seat the whole time.  I cannot tell you how many times my heart skipped a beat in this movie.  The music, the photography, the lighting, everything combined to make this a movie that I will not forget.  The music in the shower scene that is repeated at the very end (screeching violins) is forever engrained in my memory.  I tried watching this movie again by myself today and I cannot do it.  That is how scary it is.  Anthony Perkins is amazing.  Everyone in the cast is amazing, but his is the performance that you will remember from this movie.Now, about the dvd.  This dvd is incredible.  A 90-minute making of Psycho is incredible.  There is also a trailer, another documentary, and tons of other good stuff.  They really crammed a lot onto this dvd to make it worth your money.  The video quality is crystal clear.  The audio quality is stupendous.  It is only Dolby Digital stereo though.  Just be sure to crank this one to let Bernard Herrmanns score scare you out of your mind.  To sum it up, do not rent this dvd, this dvd belongs in your collection so do yourself a favor and go rent it.  But do not watch it by yourself unless you are brave.

This is by far Alfred Hitchcocks greatest film of his career, and that is something very special.Anyway you must see this film, if you have not seen it then where have you been for the last 4 decades. An absolute classic.

I just found this online. This group called Jokr has released a 2CD album of music that they call PSYCHOsync. It's supposed to be a synchronized match-up with Alfred Hitchcock's "Psycho" with their own music replacing Bernard Herrmann's original score. Of course, Herrmann's soundtrack is classic, iconic and could not be improved upon, but this haunting pop music wrings out different story lines and emotion than what is evident in the original. It reminds me of what they say you can do with Pink Floyd's "Dark Side of the Moon" and "The Wizard of Oz." You can check out their music streaming at jokrcode dot com.

Well...first let me say...you are probably thinking "o god..a 13 year old reviewing a 40 some year old movie thats black and white..hes gonna hate it." YOU ARE WRONG!I loved this movie! Just everything! It was SO suspenseful. And you think o thats the main character, nothing will happen to her! But nooooo, shes the first one to go! Dang! That was shocking! And then you have the investigator getting suspicious of the creepy hotel guy with the creppy mother. And then he gets it to from the mother! And of course the movie continues, and you just know she's gonna get caught soon! And then it gets to the climax in the basement. OMG!!! ITS A SKELETON!!!! but wait...THAT NORMON!!!!!NOT THE MOTHER!!! It was just the biggest movie shock ever! You thought it was her, but no it was the son! NOOOO WAYYY!!! I was just blown away! Just incredible! That simple.And this movie has an awesome score!!!! Soooo suspenseful!Overall, Psycho has the awesome acting, awesome plot, awesome twist, awesome score, just everything!!!! BRAVO!!!! Easily a must see!

This is without a doubt the best film i've ever seen, it never fails to scare me and it has the best and most chilling plot ever. Hitchcock's finest hour, not only his best film, but the best film ever made! it has some of the most classic scenes that has have been imitated but never mastered, the shower scene everybody knows, even if you haven't seen the movie, the absolutely terrifying final scenes in the fruit cellar is perfect horror. Anthony Perkins is so brilliant in the role that you will never be rid of the image of the character that is Norman bates, Janet Leigh, Vera Miles and John Gavin are also brilliant and create a tense atmosphere that really chills you. 100% movie making.

Compared to many of Hitchcock's other works, this movie is a bust. Although it may have been extremely scary at the time, today it is laughably bad. The story sucks and the acting isn't great.  The one thing I do give Hitchcock credit for doing well is the famous shower scene. Without it the movie would have never even been heard of.

Quite simply "The Greatest piece of Cinema EVER" Anthony Perkins is stunningly brilliant in this macabre and indeed, sad tale of a mother and son relationship. The bleak setting of the Bates Motel, combined with the haunting music of Bernard Herrmann make for a joyride of terror. I never ever fail to be engrossed, no matter how many times I see this movie.Wonderful, Wonderful stuff......and Hitchcock's directing ain't bad!!!!!

Review title: The Greatest Movie Ever Made!!!!!!(in my opinion, anyway)
Review_body: I love this movie!!!  It's my all-time absolute favorite movie in the entire world!  I have seen this movie approximately 20 - 25 times and it still scares the crap out of me!  No one, but no one, BUT ANTHONY PERKINS could ever be Norman Bates.  Alfred Hitchcock is perhaps the best director and filmmaker in history!  His films are the films which inspire young people like myself to become filmmakers, and film historians, and Hitchcock scholars, and to choose many other film careers.  It's just beyond my ability to express my love for this movie.  This was the first Hitchcock film I had ever seen, and will remain my favorite film for the rest of my life.  I even have the soundtrack!   Best movie in the world, a little cheesy by today's standards but who cares, it will make you grip the edge of your seat and your eyes pop out.  SEE IT!  YOU WILL LOVE IT!!!!!!

Alfred Hitchcock's most well-known film invented modern suspense the moment it opened in the cinema. As a child I recognized the iconic imagery and score years before I ever had the chance to watch the movie in its entirety. From the blend of music and cinematography, to its groundbreaking use of "less-is-more" violence, "Psycho" undoubtedly proves that what we see is far less important that we we DO NOT see. This film married Freud and Freddy, and redefined the horror genre as it is. It explores the often-complex relationship between mother and son, the dangers of cloistered sexuality, hidden desires, unexplored urges, dealing with death, loneliness, perversion, greed, lust, and the law.

I saw Psycho for the first time when I was seventeen; I saw it for the second time in August 2001. By that time, nothing has been the same. I love Psycho because of two main reasons: 1) in this movie you will find the best shots and the best way of directing of the cinema history; 2)Psycho is best and the easiest way to describe the human being: dreams, nightmares, hopes, obsessions, fears, wills. I'll always be grateful to Hitch for this movie: thank you, Alfred. P.S. Thanks also to Bernard Herrmann, for his dreadful but wonderful soundtrack ("the screaming violins") and to the unforgettable Norman Perkins for his interpretation of the great Norman Bates. You'll always have a special place in my heart.

This is an excellent horror film. However it does not contain a lot of gore nor is it particularly scary. It is suspenseful and has an interesting twist in the plot. The music and sound effects are well done. The black and white doesn't take anything away from the film at all. The film is perfectly named as the main character is about as nuts as you can get. The overall acting was good. The few violent scenes looked pretty cheesy, but for its time not horrible. Would recommend this film to any level of viewer from newbie all the way to movie buff. I read that this was based on Ed Gein lightly, same as Texas chainsaw massacre and Silence of the Lambs.

A near perfect film that few today can see in its intended state, ie not knowing anything about it! Hitch masterfully lulls is into thinking the film will be about a girl who takes off with a load of money - yet that has no relevance to the film in the slightest (other than to scare the hell out of you when she dies). I actually watched this film not knowing that Norman Bates was his mother and ultimately gained more from the film than a lot of people that I know have watched it.  Perfect score to the film by Bernard Herrmann which adds to the tension - see especially the music as marion is driving in the rain, and note how the windscreen wipers are a metaphor for the knife the rain is also used like the water from the shower (almost hinting at what will follow) Superb film from the master of suspense! 10/10

No matter how many times one sits through this Hitchcock classic, Anthony Perkins always manages to surprise you. It is a sensational performance - for which he didn't even get an Oscar nomination - I have no way of knowing how much preparation he dedicated to the creation of Norman Bates, maybe no more than usual, but the details of his performance are astonishing. Never a false move and if you follow the film looking into his eyes, you'll be amazed as I was. The madness and the tenderness, the danger and the cravings. A mamma's boy with hellish implications and yet we see, we feel connected to the human being, we are not horrified by him but of his circumstances. In short, we kind of understand him. That alone puts him miles and miles away from other cinematic monsters. From Richard Attenborough as the real life Christie in "10 Rillington Place" to the hideous, unredeemable Christian Bale in "American Psycho". Here Hitchcock and Herrman create an universe that Anthony Perkins inhabits with the same kind of electricity, nerve and shyness that Norman Bates projects throughout the film. Janet Leigh falls for it if not him. She, like us, sees the boy trying to escape his dutiful son's trap. He is in my list of the 10 most riveting characters ever to be captured on film.

Don't get me wrong this is a great movie,but 2 thinks i don't understand: 1.How can the detective get back to Phoenix to meet with Marion's sister from the motel in''an hour or less than a hour'' when Marion has spent 2 days on the highway to get there (first he slept on the side and the cop scene) 2.Why the corpse of killer's mother when found in the basement by Lila move like it's paranormal or something?,i know it's probably to scare you but it doesn't look nice to me.That's all i had to say if anybody can elucidate me i would be grateful,however this was a great movie to watch i really enjoyed it it's one of the best suspense/horror movie indeed,especially cause it's made the 60"

The original screening of "Psycho" was released at the former (untitled) Westwood theatre at Pico and Westwood Blvd. in Westwood California, (since than that theatre has been replaced by the Westwood Mall.) A selected invitational viewing was privately projected for the guests, cast and crew prior to it's release. As an undisclosed surreptitiously disguised Hitchcock enigma, this version was edited with a subliminal avant-garde inclusion of a craftily illustrated "Skull and Crossbones symbol" and spliced into the film after every nine frames of the shower and detective's butchering scenes. Whether or not once the film industry's critics discovered and banned this effect and allowed Hitchcock to continue projecting this version extensively was unknown, but by the time this well-scripted "Psycho" was publicly released the fear factor had already been commonly reputed. The silence, suspended action, proceeded by the dramatic music, and the aerial jump cut filming made it a sleepless producing journey of celluloid-fanaticism. After attending this private screening I was scared out of my innocent mind. A few weeks proceeded and upon it's release to the local theaters, rumor had it that the shrewd Hitchcock created some hanky-panky with this film, so we examined the reel from our local theater's projection room, and discovered the subconscious inclusion of his secret confidential editing. Due to the critical film industry's mere political influence, Hitchcock had to remove this phenomenal strategy. By its reputation alone since "Nosferatu," "Psycho" had already stood patented as the most horrifying visual experience ever. "Psycho" really didn't need any editing enhancement. Viewing it again recently still sends chills through my skin!The psychiatrist at the climax of this film played a key role and scene of it's finale who explained the events of the nature of what took place at this spine-tingling escapade.The geniuses of Alfred Hitchcock and Anthony Perkins will not be forgotten...may they Rest In Peace.

Exceptional movie. I'm a particular fan of horrors, but I hate the ones that are all gore and no plot. Psycho has hardly any gore, but got me yelling with satisfying fright.Black and white really works with this movie. It's easier to see ominous shadows and I was tense the whole time, on the alert for flickering shapes. The images were beautifully taped. The plot is complex and very thought-provoking, and went along well with my love for all things psychology.My favorite movie changes nearly monthly, but this is definitely going to be my favorite for a long while. Shortly after seeing it, I couldn't stop thinking about it and I researched my favorite scenes on Youtube and made my computer desktop a picture of Norman Bates.Only Hitchcock could have made such a great film!
This is an ageless movie and unquestionably one of the best one that Hitchcock has ever created.

Psycho is known as the world's first slasher film. Psycho is know 50 years old and it is my one of my favorite films of all time.In this wonderful Hitchcock vehicle, you follow a young woman (played by Janet Leigh) who embezzles $40,000 to give to her boyfriend, who is trying to pay off his father's debt and pay his wife's alimony. During the drive, you are kept in suspense, thinking that she will be caught, due to the fact that she can't hide her emotions.In this movie, you are looking for a private island, but you find a private trap, set brilliantly by Sir Alfred Hitchcock. This movie is also well known for the shocking shower scene (say that five times fast). Now that everyone knows about that scene, first time watchers will know what happens, they will be expecting it. What first-timers don't know is when.I personally like the stairs scene. Everyone talks about the shower, almost no one ever talks about the scene where Martin Balsam walks up the stairs of the Bates home. After watching the movie the first time, I was afraid to go up the stairs. That doesn't me that the shower scene didn't affect me. I hate it when people come in the bathroom when I take a shower.The plot is great. At first, you believe it is about this girl, but really it is about a motel owner who was dominated by his mother his whole life. Then, at the end, our whole view of the plot then twists, which is what makes it my favorite movie. But I can't reveal it. You'll have to watch it for yourself.

The film Psycho is about a woman named Marion who sneaks away from her old life, after stealing a large sum of money from her employer. On her way to see her fiancé, she finds herself at the desolate Bates Motel, whose owner turns out to be the namesake for the title of the film: a psycho. After obsessing about his dead mother for so long, he psychologically turned into her persona at times. The women Norman Bates kills, were killed when his mother's persona was in charge.The main characters are Norman Bates, and Marion Crane, portrayed by Anthony Perkins and Janet Leigh, respectively.The overall theme of this movie seems to deal with the uncertainty of unfamiliar people. When Marion, the main character, happens to meet the socially-awkward Norman Bates, she probably couldn't have imagined getting murdered by him. The message seems to be that you can never really know if the next person you meet is truly crazy.A movie with a similar theme is Hitchhiker, in which a person driving across the country picks up a hitchhiker, who ultimately does many sadistic things to the driver. In that movie, it was also clear that you just don't know which strangers to trust.Perhaps the most famous scene in Psycho is the one in which Marion is stabbed to death in the shower, frequently referred to as the "shower scene", in pop culture. This scene is shot and pieced together with many short clips, all shot at different angles. The constant views at different angles make the scene more suspenseful and frightening, in my opinion. Although the attacker in the scene remains obscure, it appears to be that of a woman. Ultimately, it is revealed that Norman also dresses as "Mother", whenever he thinks he is "Mother".Another scene that best exemplifies how crazy Norman is, is the final scene, in which he's locked up in a prison cell. "Mother" is thinking that everyone has it wrong – he wouldn't even hurt a fly! The camera closes in upon him as "Mother's" thoughts are narrated. And in the close-up of Norman, an eerie feeling is truly conveyed.When this film was first released, I think it was a first of its kind in some aspects. I think that never before, a murder had been so graphic in a movie. Although, compared to some modern movies (such as Saw), Psycho would be considered a very mild murder film.But in any case, I believe the film was cutting-edge for the day, and remains a classic tribute to a man who truly was "Psycho".

Review title: A great ride for a suspense movie.
Review_body: When I saw for the first time this movie, I don't have any idea of what it will come, or the story in yet. Except, the obvious things like The Murderer scene, or the motel. I only know that Norman is gonna turn mad at some time (I was watching the 2nd season of Bates Motel in that time) and, by the first minutes, everything that I think was "WTF I'm I watching?" everything was so "happy" in some ways that I seriously doubt that I was watching "Psycho", but like 40 or 30 minutes later, everything just blow up my mind. The twist that Hitchcock gives to the movie in the way that he does... just another director simply cannot do it. The minutes before the "End" words appears, I admit that I feel very excited about the whole film. I was so proud of being watching that film, and so awful about don't seeing before. "Psycho" was an "after" and "before" in my movie tastes. I totally recommend it.

Review title: Unexpectedly dull movie for the modern times
Review_body: Granted, this movie might be of a lot of artistic value, with all the cinematography amongst other things, and also it might have scared a lot of people in the older generations. But I don't see any reason why this movie should be rated 1st amongst the Horror movie genre top 10 in contemporary times. Imagine an average Joe who wants to spend his precious weekend day watching a good horror flick with his girlfriend to get to cosying up. He would expect the no. 1 in horror genres on IMDb to be pretty scary to say the least. Not only did this movie failed to "horrify" the both of us, we did not find this much of an entertaining thriller as well(as it is just that--a thriller). Not sure why it's listed in the horror category. Do not recommend this movie if your situation is similar to what I described above. Maybe if you're a movie enthusiast who loves the cinematographic detail, go ahead...

Hitchcock movies are my favorite! Psycho by far is the best of all of the Hitchcock movies. I am only 47, but have been a fan of Hitchcock movies since I was 19 and saw Psycho II in the movie theater back in 1983. When I saw the black/white clip of Psycho in the beginning of the Psycho II movie, I was hooked and had to see the original that started it all. Movies today don't come close to those made by Hitchcock back then. Remakes can never match the original. The acting was tremendous. I was always a fan of Anthony Perkins' work and loved Janet Leigh as Marion Crane. The filming, the scenery, the old cars, all of it had me hooked from the beginning. Psycho is the best!

There is not an abundance of subtlety or the lately familiar Hitchcock bent toward significant and colorful scenery in this obviously low- budget job. With a minimum of complication, it gets off to a black-and- white start with the arrival of a fugitive girl with a stolen bankroll at an eerie motel.Well, perhaps it doesn't get her there too swiftly. That's another little thing about this film. It does seem slowly paced for Mr. Hitchcock and given over to a lot of small detail. But when it does get her to the motel and apparently settled for the night, it turns out this isolated haven is, indeed, a haunted house.The young man who diffidently tends it -- he is Anthony Perkins and the girl is Janet Leigh -- is a queer duck, given to smirks and giggles and swift dashes up to a stark Victorian mansion on a hill. There, it appears, he has a mother -- a cantankerous old woman -- concealed. And that mother, as it soon develops, is deft at creeping up with a knife and sticking holes into people, drawing considerable blood.That's the way it is with Mr. Hitchcock's picture -- slow buildups to sudden shocks that are old-fashioned melodramatics, however effective and sure, until a couple of people have been gruesomely punctured and the mystery of the haunted house has been revealed. Then it may be a matter of question whether Mr. Hitchcock points of psychology, the sort of highly favored by Krafft-Ebing, are as reliable as his melodramatic stunts.Frankly, we feel his explanations are a bit of leg-pulling by a man who has been known to resort to such tactics in his former films.The consequence is his denouement falls quite flat for us. But the acting is fair. Mr. Perkins and Miss Leigh perform with verve, and Vera Miles, John Gavin and Martin Balsam do well enough in other roles.The one thing we would note with disappointment is that, among the stuffed birds that adorn the motel office of Mr. Perkins, there are no significant bats.

Always watch this when it is showing. I remember when I was a kid hearing my mom talking about this film especially the shower scene. I knew I would have to see it at some point. Eventually saw it on tv years later and it didn't disappoint. And it still doesn't to this day. In 2015 it was on the big screen as part of a Fathom Events series and I had to see it in this form. So I took my youngest daughter with me who had never seen it. She was gripping her seat throughout. And this was a kid who grew up watching 80s slasher films. Mission accomplished. This movie is the template for those slasher movies. In the first scene it is obvious that Marion (Janet Leigh) and Sam (John Gavin) are in a sordid relationship. In that later genre this seals her fate. And her sister Lila (Vera Miles) is the original "Last Girl". The story is superb. Great acting ( although John Gavin is mediocre) especially Anthony Perkins as Norman . The black-and-white cinematography escalates the creepiness effect. And the music score? Even people who have never seen this film are familiar with it. The camera effects outstanding. The shots when Vera Miles approached the house to confront Mrs. Bates. As for my daughter, the climactic scene in the fruit cellar freaked her out. I would say that is great filmmaking.

'Psycho' is Alfred Hitchcock's true masterpiece.  Every frame of this movie is intentional, and as a film student, I highly recommend it to any person who is interested in directing or simply in viewing movies as art instead of entertainment.  Hidden within every moment, every camera angle is a metaphor or foreshadowing of what is to come.The unusual plot structure (I will not go into details, I do not want to spoil anything) is just another reason why this movie merits at least one viewing.  The acting by Anthony Perkins is stunning, bone-chilling, unforgettable.  This movie scared me half to death, and the surprise ending shocked me; there is nothing predictable about 'Psycho'.And whatever you do - do NOT compare it to the sequels or remakes.  This is a masterpiece as it stands ALONE.  Still, despite those unfortunate rip-offs, 'Psycho' is a classic - and for good reason.

The fact that Perkins could never escape this role proves that he played the part perhaps too well.And that ending, I wasn't expecting that! Hitchcock at his best! This must been one of the best suspense/thriller/ horror films i've seen. No other movie had the impact and the greatness of this. And the story behind the movie is really something, not only the book that inspired the movie but also the behind the scenes (i recommend that you take a look at the movie Hitchcock with Anthony Hopkins and Helen Mirren or read a little about it, it's very interesting). Perkins makes a terrific performance as Norman Bates (the best i've seen). Janet Leigh equally fantastic, and don't forget Vera Miles, John Gavin and the detective Arbogast (Martin Balsam) who made also a great job. One of the greatest horror/suspense films I have ever seen. If you haven't seen this, put it at the top of your list.

Review title: Not a real killer of a film
Review_body: Not a real killer of a filmThis review contains spoilersPsycho is a film made by Alfred Hitchcock in 1960, in this film you follow Marion Crane who has stolen $40.000 and who is therefore on the run, she is planning to use the money to marry her beloved Sam in California. On the way there however, the weather had turned very bad and she was forced to sleep at a remote motel where she meets Norman, an innocent young man who seems to have a strong relationship with his mother, who is the owner of the motel, and he also seems very harmless. When Marion goes missing however Sam and her sister investigate her missing together and they come to a horrible conclusion. *SPOILERS* When the private detective Arbogast goes to investigate the house of Norman and his mother but he gets killed as well. Sam and Lila (Marion's sister) go to the deputy's office to find out about Normans mother but the deputy tells them that Normans mother is long dead and buried. They go to the motel in disguise as a married couple and search Marion's room, Sam is suspicious and starts to interrogate Norman and tries to make him confess to the murder but Norman knocks Sam out, in the meantime Lila goes to the house on top of the hill and starts to look around there. When she sees Norman approaching she hides in the basement and she finds Normans mother there in a chair but she is dead and rotten. Suddenly Norman comes in from behind with a wig similar to his mothers hair and also clothes that look like his mothers, just before he can stab Lila Sam comes in from behind and subdues him. The shot then changes into a police station where you can see Norman in a chair and talking to himself like he is his mother. *ENDING SPOILERS*Psycho was a rather revolutionary film when it came out. This was because of the shocking ideas, the good camera-work and new ways of producing. Nowadays the ideas aren't shocking anymore and the new ways of producing isn't new. The camera-work is still interesting though. Combined with the music and the special effects it created a lot of tension in some parts of the movie. Because of this the producer Alfred Hitchcock is sometimes called: The master of suspense. It is too bad that the movie had a slow progressing plot, because this causes people to lose their attention. Things like this show us how old the movie actually is, nowadays movie-plots progress really fast to keep the attention of the viewers, but at that time Psycho had a fast-progressing plot. The standards for movies have changed. In our opinion Psycho is getting past its expirations date. The setting of the movie is mostly at the motel of Norman Bates. The place has a dark atmosphere and especially Norman Bates house. The camera-work in the film was good because it was focused on a lot, for example in the famous shower scene over 70 different camera positions were used so you know the director worked hard on the scene to make it as good as he could. The film is also a first of its kind in many aspects, a toilet being flushed and seeing Marion in her underwear, of course nowadays this is not really special to us but back then this was very revolutionary. The use of sound in the film was good because it created a lot of tense moments an when the music started to play you knew something bad was going to happen. The special effects were bad for us though because we automatically compare them to the special effects that are used in films now even though we try not to and they are really laughable. Editing was used effectively in this film and it had to too, because if we again look at the shower scene you never see Marion actually get stabbed but because the film was edited in such a way you automatically know she did get stabbed this is also the case in the scene where the private investigator got stabbed. Then there is the plot, the part of the film that made the film so bad for us, the plot progresses very slowly and it was hard to not get distracted while watching the film, if there was any action which was rare it would only last for a couple of seconds or minutes if you were lucky. We thought the film was not that amazing for us. The film was hard to understand and it was a very slow story. You have to watch it several times to understand everything in full detail. This is very usual in Hitchcock's films so we could have expected this. The film was not very action packed in comparison to today's standard, nowadays we have much more action in films than there was in psycho. The special effects are not that special, but again that has to do with the standards from today. It was not an interesting movie for us however if you look on the other side of things psycho was a renewing movie. Everything was original at that time and the movie was made from a low budget. It set the standard for thriller movies today and the film will always be an example. You will like the movie if you want a good story but if you want more action and adventure we would not recommend this movie.

This is my first review on IMDb and what a place to start! Psycho is one of those rare thrillers that you can watch over and over again. The film keeps you glued to your seat throughout it's entire length. The performances are all top class. These facts are all only too well known about the film. Psycho is the BEST psychological-horror thriller I have ever seen. All suspense movies made ever since don't compare at all to this fantastic film. I have seen all but 3 of Hitchcock's movies, and this one is the BEST he ever made. If you love suspense, I highly recommend you watch this film. Buy it! ALfred Hitchcock turns a seemingly grim story into a masterpiece of a film. Marion Crane (Janet Leigh) embezzles some money. She goes to meet her boyfriend whom she wishes to marry, and on the way decides to stay at the Bates Motel. If you want to find out what happens next, you'll just have to watch the movie. :) I promise you, it is a movie you won't soon forget. WARNING Psycho is not a movie to be seen by anyone under 13, due to it's violent content. Still, it is a fascinating movie to be enjoyed by more MATURE audiences. I love Psycho! When I began watching this movie I felt that a film from the year 1960 couldn't possibly have an effect on somebody who has seen all the major horror movies of the last 30 years or so. Exorcist, Omen, The Shining, Friday the 13th, etc. etc. etc. etc. Never have I watched a movie that layered such powerful emotional scenarios into digestible brain food that nourishes the darkest places of my psyche. . As the movie went on I felt Norman Bates' madness slowly bubble and build so exquisitely that it was indeed a guilty pleasure to witness his final all out blitzkrieg into sheer madness. At this breaking point it was I too who had lived the moment with all of the unfortunate guests of the Bates Motel. Oh I am not a psycho per SE, but after watching this movie I felt like I lived every experience in the first person. It was after the movie directly after the last scene that I realized that a movie this special had eluded my eyes for so long. I almost felt heartbroken because it would have been the horror/terror movie to judge all others. I recommend to any teenager getting into film to really watch this, perhaps alone, perhaps not. I am just floored by the powerful use of music and the absolute shock value. The psychological thriller was born from this film. I thought SEVEN was shocking, and to some degree it was. But I was shocked deep to my core after viewing this masterpiece. Nothing in film will shock me ever again, I truly believe this. This Hitchcock fellow was something special. It took me 30 years to see this, and its much more than just a shower scene. Thats only the beginning. Oh the classics. Lets not confuse Classic with Old like so many of us are so quick to do. This movie transcends Classic and is more modern than the stuff Hollywood is pushing out these days. Still shocking after 46 years.

What can really be said about a classic like 'Psycho' without being entirely obvious? This amazing film remains beautifully subtle, and creepily haunting. From the set design, to the perfectly executed shower scene, to the final interrogation scene that really proves it is the average, 'normal' ones to look out for, this film is perfection. (And the 'Bates Motel' series it inspired is not too shabby, either.) Was the actor who played Norman Bates ever able to find another role after this film? I know as a director, myself, I would never be able to get past such a creepy character. And Janet Leigh? Also a brilliant actor choice. All in all, this is a brilliant film made by an insanely talented, but deeply troubled man. Regardless, though, thanks, Hitch.

I generally find the oldest movies are overrated just because they are "classics" but this truly is a classic. It may be slower than most modern movies today, although you really follow the plot, and feel the evil and insanity that lies within Norman Bates. You will feel like this was the first real horror movie ever made (although it's actually not) This truly is a timeless classic. Review title: Simply the Best Mystery Movie of All Time
Review_body: There are rarely any movies that revolutionize a whole genre. Hitchcock's Psycho is undoubtedly one such movie. The movie unfolds at a pace which is perfect according to modern standards. It is a guarantee you'll be spiked on your seats for the entire length of the movie. The acting is outclass with special reference being to Anthony Perkins, the stammering motel manager and of course Vera Miles (also John Gavins acting for me). Hitchcock brings out his best direction techniques and methods in this movie. Everything about this movie just stands out, its cinematography, acting, direction, story telling.. just everything. The plot, though simple, is created with so much suspense that you'll be submerged into the movie. The climax may well be the best we have ever seen (not even comparable to climax in The Usual Suspects). For the climax alone i would rank the movie 10/10. This is one horror/mystery movie that revolutionized the way mystery movies were made. All assured, Vera Miles' screaming picture would be etched in your mind for a long time. A definite watch.

Alfred Hitchcocks "Physco" is truly classic horror film, with the main character: Lila Crane who's played by actress Vera Miles is abandoning her previous life with a stolen forty thousand dollars. In her process of escaping she ends up checking in to a remote motel which is run by a young male, Norman Bates (Anthony Perkins) who is strongly controlled by his mother, even though she died on the 10th of June, 1949.The use of shades and shadows throughout the film sets an eerie theme to the entire film. With one of the best scenes taken from behind a shower curtain, at this point you can only see Lila Crane as a silhouette of a person with a knife appears behind the shower curtain, Lila Crane then meets a grizzly demise as she is attacked. The mystery of the character leads you to believe it was either Norma or Norman Bates but at this time you are unaware of Norma Bate's death, so you are torn between the friendly but creepy Norman or the unseen (Except for a shadow in her bedroom window) Norma. The fast edits and audio throughout this scene represent the chaos that is currently taking place, the screeching of a violin shows that it is a violent attack and is used to shock the audience with loud and uncommon sounds. The final scene of the film shows Norman Bates in the prison cell alone, the frame starts of as a wide shot but is slowly getting closer to Normans face while a voice over, which is in his mothers voice is talking about how he's not even going to hurt a fly. This show's that he has truly gone insane and believes he is fully innocent. As the framing of the shot comes closer to his face, he looks into the camera and smiles while the screen fades to the vehicle where he hid Lila Crane's body that is being pulled from the swamp. For a brief second in this shot you see his mothers corpse' teeth over the top of his smile, this represents that his mother's half of his mind has taken over.

Review title: Brilliant and suspense lasts till the very end.
Review_body: Unlike the thriller movies of today, this movie is different. It isn't one of those movies with the obvious ending. The suspense will keep you waiting till the very end. The ending will make your jaw drop it is that brilliant, you will watch it again and again.If you are one of those people against black and white movies, thinking they are 'too old', give this movie a try because you would never guess what is going to happen and you will talk about it forever. Everything about this movie has been performed to it's best and the ending will leave you rendered speechless.My favorite horror movie of all time, it is definitely worth a watch.

Review title: Hitchcock takes you for an enjoyable winding ride
Review_body: A brilliant example of a classic Hitchcock technique that has been matched by none is his ability to draw the audience's attention to a very specific item in the film, only to have that item end up completely irrelevant in the end. Marion stealing the $40,000 seems crucial to where the film is going when it happens, and when you realize that it holds no real relevance to the plot, it intensifies the classic and surprising ending. Hitchcock has a way of leading the watcher one way and immediately taking a sharp turn in another direction - a true testament to why he is one of the greatest filmmakers in history.

Review title: My favourite film of all time!
Review_body: By far the greatest work of The Master of Suspense, Alfred Hitchcock. When I watched this film for the first time aged 16, I was sucked in by the plot, the characters, Bernard Herrmann's score and the terrific acting. I went in knowing one thing about the movie, and that was that there is a shower scene. It was the first Hitchcock film I'd ever seen and it was the first mystery/thriller I'd ever seen. Now I am a big fan of both Hitch and the genre.The best aspect of this movie is the fantastic acting. What can you say that hasn't already been said about the performance of Anthony Perkins as Norman Bates except that it's a tragedy he wasn't nominated for an Oscar. His delivering of the script, his shyness and sudden twists is one of the best acting performances I've witnessed. But that doesn't take away from the rest of the cast. Janet Leigh is wonderful Marion Crane, and supporting talent from John Gavin, Martin Balsam and especially Vera Miles, make for a film you can watch over and over.This is the first film I ever saw where afterwards, I wanted to know everything there was to know about it. I watched all the making of documentaries I could find, I wanted to watch all the sequels (Psycho II is also very good by the way) and I even chose the film as my specialist subject in a quiz we did in my college.I recommend this film to everyone. It's full of twists, turns and surprises that keep you guessing write till the end, and I mean the very end. You can't take your eyes of the screen. You're engrossed by these characters and the plot that you don't want to miss a second.Suspenseful, sophisticated, chilling, thrilling and an absolute masterpiece of film making.

I always admire Hitchcock with the way he storyboards all of his movies and this is one great example of such. I always look up to him whenever I try and get my film together. Cinematic and one of the best films of all time. If you haven't seen this movie then you are missing out. Make sure that you put it on your movie cue.

An excellent classic horror flick. Hitchcock raised the bar for all horror movies without showing any blood, guts or nudity. A trailblazer for his time indeed. Hitchcock deliberately wanted "Psycho" to look like a cheap exploitation film. . . That is the mystery of why Hitchcock marred the ending of a masterpiece with a sequence that is grotesquely out of place. Whenever anyone speaks about Psycho, the first images that come to mind are those of Janet Leigh being hacked to death in the shower. The scene is so famous that even people who have not seen the movie are aware of it. Bernard Herrmann's strident, discordant music has been used in countless other movies to denote the appearance of a "psycho." The brilliance of the scene lies in the editing. Those who go frame-by-frame through it will note how much is left to the imagination. We see a knife, blood (actually chocolate syrup), water, and a woman's naked body (with certain parts strategically concealed from the camera), but only briefly is the penetration of the blade into the flesh shown*. The full horror of the murder is only hinted at on-screen. It takes the power of the viewer's imagination to fill in the blanks. Brilliant movie indeed.

Often referred to as the most famous and influential horror film of all time, Psycho broke down all barriers of comfort and escape when going to the pictures. With people fainting and screaming uncontrollably in their seats at the time of release, the film is still as unsettling and nerve-wrecking as it was 50 years ago, and has cemented Alfred Hitchcock as the true master of suspense.Adapted from the significantly less successful novel from Robert Bloch, Marion Crane (Janet Leigh) is a young attractive woman who has stolen $40,000 from the bank where she works, in order to runaway with her already-married lover. After driving all night in pouring rain, she stops at the Bates motel off the freeway for a night-in, and meets the nervous, bumbling Norman Bates (Anthony Perkins) who is quite taken with her upon first sight. In one of the most staggering sequences in film history, she is stabbed to death while taking a shower, and as she is reported missing and people begin looking for her, the truth of Norman Bates and his 'motel' will be revealed.Never before had the main character been brutally murdered only halfway through - let alone an attractive leading lady - and never before had such a brutal antagonist been so normal, relatable and above all, human. Beautifully shot in black and white and carried by an unforgettable score from the late Bernard Herrmann, Hitchcock in all his genius draws us in with a twisted concoction of sex, murder and madness, never letting us forget even to this day that real horror may be right around the corner. All the performances are top-notch, particularly that of Perkins who as cinema's most unlikely serial killer stumbles through the film with every breath of confidence stripped from him by his overbearing invalid mother.

I love Psycho so much I can't begin to describe what it means to me. The trouble is it has been over-sold in the last twenty years or so that it is known as the film with THAT scene in the shower. There's so much more to it than that. It is arguably the most influential film ever made, and the best directed one at that. Without it, there would be no Jaws, no Godfather, no Star Wars. Psycho may not be the greatest film ever made, nor the scariest film ever made, but is probably the best crafted thriller and a fine example of cinematic manipulation. Psycho continues to influence filmmakers. Look at the Psycho references in 2005's Houseof Wax (preservered mother, twin sons/ split personality, scary house on the hill.) Psycho is simply Great.

Review title: One of if not the best horror movies
Review_body: This is hands down Hitchcock's best film. If only they made movies like this nowadays. The acting is suburb especially for the era the film was made and of course the directing is brilliant. Anthony Perkins does an amazing job as Norman Bates and really made a lasting performance. You really feel he has an unhealthy relationship with his dead mother and you you may be thrown of by the fact he committed the murders, after a while you think "I knew it". He is like that weird kid at school who you know is going to snap. In my opinion, he made the movie. Of course he didn't do it alone he had Very Mills, Janet Leigh, and many more supporting actors/actresses. This movie really keeps you hooked until the incredible ending and keeps you on the edge of your seat throughout. This is one of those movies that scares you without using cheap jump scares or tons of gore. One of the major factors contributing to the scare level is the soundtrack. I'm sure most people know the music played over the infamous shower scene, but people overlook the eerie music played throughout the film. I really suggest any horror fan...any movie fan to check this masterpiece from the master of the macabre.

anyone who calls this the "greatest film of all time" needs to watch more films, especially films from other countries around the world.Psycho does a few tricks on its audience but other than that, it has nothing much to qualify it as a "great film."technically, it's also nothing great. if you're looking for good technique in a Hitchcock film, you're better off watching The Birds.psychologically, it's also nothing impressive. sure its main reference is Freud's Oedipus Complex, but many films before it has already explored that, albeit in different ways.sure, it's surprising that the first protagonist dies halfway through the film.and sure, the twist at the end is awesome.but "the greatest film of all time"?you need to get out more often.

Review title: A horror thriller that will keep you hanging onto your chair!
Review_body: PSYCHO (1960)Directed By: Alfred HitchcockBook Base: Robert Block Screen Play: Joseph StephaniMusic: Bernard Hermann Cinematography: John Russell Film Editing by: George TomasiniCast: Anthony Perkins (Norman Bates),Vera Miles (Lila Crane), John Gavin (Sam Louis), Marion Crane (Janet Leigh)Psycho is an astounding film produced and directed by Alfred Hitchcock. Hitchcock is known for Movies with surprise endings while keeping you wondering what will happen next. This film is a must see for everyone, even those who do not like horror movies.The movie is about a woman, Marion Crain (Janet Leigh)who seems to be a little on the naughty side, but honest. Marion is honest until the day she decides to steal $40,000 in cash from her employer. Marion leaves town by vehicle to be with her boyfriend who is penniless. Marion travels a long distance and starts to get tired and pulls into the Bates Motel. She has a surprise waiting for her there. The plot thickens from here. I will not go into plot detail for those of you who have not viewed the film, but the suspense is uncanny in the way Hitchcock directed the movie.Hitchcock uses music and lighting in a way that draws the audience's full attention and makes the viewers become a part of the film. The suspense in this film is beyond comprehension, in the way that a person has not lived until you have viewed this film. No film of this time has been able to top this suspenseful thriller. The fact that the movie is in black and white makes the film unusually dramatic. Viewers thought Notorious was good, but Psycho is even better. Hitchcock has plenty of surprises and keeps his audience guessing. The dramatic lighting, camera angles, and suspenseful music make Psycho one of his best.If you have seen the 1998 version of this film, it does not do Hitchcock's 1960's version justice. The camera angles and lighting are much better in the 1960 version and keep the audience in suspense throughout. The newer version has dead zones, and the suspense is broken up. The coloring in the later film does not give the audience the feeling of standing in the scene watching what is going on. The acting in the newer film is extremely poor and boring.The 1960's original screenplay, Psycho is almost guaranteed to make you hang onto your chair throughout the movie, even if you are viewing a movie on a cell phone. I would not recommend watching this film alone for sure.Reference: Hitchcock, A. (Director),(1960) Psycho (Motion Picture).

Janet Leigh plays Marion Crane, a woman who is in love with a divorced man Sam Loomis. He says once he pays his ex wife off with the alimony, they'll get married. When Marion's boss asks her to put their most valued client's money, $40,000 to be exact, and bring it to the bank. She has other plans though, she takes the money for herself and flee's the city, but not before her boss sees her driving off. Shaky enough, huh? But she pulls over to get a nap in, and a police officer asks if she's OK, but she gets shaky and just wants to drive off. The policemen fallows her since she is so shaky and she ends up buying a different car. She gets caught in a giant rainstorm and pulls over to the Bates Motel.She meets there, the owner, a pleasant and polite young man, Norman Bates. He lives in the house next to the motel with his mother. Marion checks in and Norman offers her dinner, they have a conversation mostly about his mom and Marion is concerned when she heard screams from the house that sounded like his mom. Norman gets on the defenses and asks Marion some questions as well, she says she is going to a "private island". Norman is very attracted to her, you can tell immediately, and she leaves knowing that she has to get out of the trap she set for herself back in Phoenix. As she's taking a shower before bed, a mysterious figure comes to the curtain and opens it stabbing Marion violently several times causing her to die. Norman cleans up the mess and gets rid of her body not knowing about her money and throwing that away too.

Anyone can see that villains have become the 'New Heroes' in today's cinema. There are countless examples but one of the biggest is Norman in 'Psycho'. How are filmmakers able to successfully use villains as the hero? There are a couple articles that look into this question a little more, it also looks into why they use the hero. The articles "Movie villains are more interesting than movie heroes" by Alana Pedalino and "Villains and Antiheros" by Lisa Agnew might begin to help us understand the producers reasoning for taking out the hero.In this article "Movie villains are more interesting than movie heros" goes into more of the villain part. This Article talks about the purpose of a villain in cinema. There's a quote from this article, "We're supposed to love hating the villain, yet we can't help hating that we love him." Says Pedalino. This article might be able to better help people understand why filmmakers are using the anti hero strategy and why it actually can work. Pedalino tells us that the filmmakers are playing more towards the real life scenarios. While watching the hero defeat the villain is satisfying it is not real life, and people soon forget their feelings towards the film. Whereas watching a scenario where the villain either defeats the hero or gets very close to doing so, leaves us with mixed feelings.

Review title: Psycho by Alfred Hitchcock is a must see
Review_body: Being often nicknamed, "The Master of Suspense", Alfred Hitchcock certainly does not disappoint in his black and white film, Psycho (1960), with his certain use of psychological examination of his characters that will have you intrigued from the very beginning of his film. Psycho is a classic horror film that challenges the genre for a contemporary audience, a rush of chaotic fear and madness as suspenseful as you would have predicted from the movie that started the slasher genre itself. Despite a slower pace and dated special effects, it's a well crafted if unconventional horror film. Along with it's creativity, it has a more engaging plot filled with more visual disturbing than almost any other film in the horror genre.Hitchcock does this by building a connection to his audience to the characters. By getting into the main character, Marion Crane's (Janet Leigh) mind at an early start of the film, has you not only engaged but intensively worried already of what will happen to her. Being a secretary in Phoenix, Marion's conscience drives her insane when she decides to steal 40,000 dollars from a client in order to run away with her love, Sam Loomis (John Gavin). With an eerie feel, you are sucked into the movie trying to figure out how and why things are happening to her. The buildup adds to the intensity of the unknown of who is the killer and why their motives are the way that they are.As Marion Crane tries to run farther away from her problems, not only has she found herself in a huge rainstorm but also exhausted from the endless thoughts of her conscience mind. Having to pull over she is luckily able to find the flickering lights of the Bates Motel to stay the night. There she meets the polite, man of few words, Norman Bates (Anthony Perkins). Norman welcomes Marion to her stay by casual talk over sandwiches and milk. Norman then explains his interest in taxidermy and his unique relationship with his mother. Hitchcock sets the scene of this encounter by his ability of using foreshadowing with little details of Norman's parlor where the scene takes place. It is there where we find out more about his overbearing, domineering mother. Throughout the entire film, viewers have a sense of suspense always being displayed whether it is through the mysterious music, the director's use of certain angles, or even just the unknown of what we as the audience understand. Hitchcock finds a way of having you always questioning and in a way, overwhelmed with emotions while watching his films. Viewers that are from my generation could say that to be even considered a "horror" film or even a "thriller" there must be a certain amount of violence or gore to reach this criteria.However, in 1960, horrified viewers saw Psycho as such a thrilling film and to be surprisingly not explicitly violent which our generation today would be uncommonly found in the latest horror, thriller films. Hitchcock doesn't use the violent gestures to make his film what it is. It is about the psychological intellect that he so deliberately has the audience feel. It is about the buildup and the mysterious overall mood of his masterpiece that has you leaving wanting more.If the definition of a good thriller to you is gore and violence, Psycho wouldn't necessarily be the movie for you. Not meaning to say that there isn't a scene or two that will take you by surprise, but there is so much more than the gruesome feel to this movie. It is Hitchcock's way of giving his audience enough suspense, curiosity, and most of all, that thrilling feel that makes the must see Psycho what it is, a worldwide phenomenon.

Recorded in 1960, Psycho is a film that will remain an ageless classic due to chiefly to the superb storytelling of Alfred Hitchcock. Similar to Robert Wise's film The Haunting, Hitchcock is able to use the audience's imagination against them. Just like the fact that no ghosts are visible in The Haunting, Psycho does not actually show violence. Instead, it is implied and more terrifying that way. Hitchcock's use of sound in this movie makes it more suspenseful as well. Particular creepy is the sharp violin music that plays just before a character is brutally murdered. Hitchcock also uses foreshadowing to create added levels of suspense throughout the film.Janet Leigh plays Marion Crane in the film. She steals $40,000 from her employer in an attempt to get away from the daily stresses of life with actor John Gavin who plays character Sam Loomis. Marion flees Phoenix to join Sam in Fairvale, but the journey is long and Marion is forced to stop for the night. Fearing that she will be caught, Marion chooses to stay at a run-down hotel that is off the beaten track. It is at this hotel where Marion meets Norman Bates who is played by Anthony Perkins. Unknown to Marion, Norman is a violent psychopath who develops an alter ego as his mother. Unable to control himself, Norman eventually stabs Marion to death, puts her body in the truck of her car, and pushes her car into a muddy pond on the property to dispose of the evidence.After Marion's mysterious disappearance, her sister Lila who played by Vera Miles, goes in search of her at Sam's place of employment in Fairvale. Actor Martin Balsam plays Private Detective Arbogast who is hired to track down Marion and the missing money. Arbogast assumes that Marion went to see Sam, so he questions Sam and Lila about her whereabouts. With no leads to go on, Arbogast tries to retrace what would most likely have been Marion's trip from Phoenix to Fairvale. It is during his investigation that Arbogast stops at the Bates Motel and talks to Norman. Norman eventually admits that Marion was at his hotel, but claims that she left. Unconvinced, Arbogast alerts Sam and Lila that he has found a trail and that he is going back to try and talk to Norman's mother.In order to know what will come of the investigation, one will have to watch the film. However, one thing is very clear and that is the theme of this film. Be wary of traveling alone and not letting anyone know where you are going because you never know when you will run into someone like Norman Bates.
