Alfred Hitchcock's 'Psycho' is arguably one of the most classic horror movies ever made. A great deal of iconography associated with the horror genre these days, for example eerie orchestral soundtracks and use of shadows and simplicity, appear to have originated in this movie.The narrative follows Marion, a young female secretary, who steals a large sum of money from her employer and runs away with the intent of building a new life with her lover. On her journey to her boyfriend's place of work, however, she decides against this action but as it is too dark to either go home or continue the journey she stops to spend the night at a motel. Namely the 'Bates Motel'... Many of the scenes that follow have become infamous in the world of cinema. When Marion is being shown to be stabbed in the shower very little is seen of the murderer and there is very little noticeable blood. Hitchcock clearly knew the way in which to create real horror is through what is NOT seen. Audiences' imaginations tend to scare them the most. The film continues to scare the audiences until the very last scene, which is unusual for a horror film. In typical, mediocre, horror films a new equilibrium is usually created and the horror dead or over. But although the film does typically end on a note of normality (albeit with characters having been murdered) Norman Bates is still alive and as creepy as ever, if not more than to begin with. The film works on a number of levels. It fulfils many different categories of horror, in the sense that it displays blood and murder, but also has psychological disturbances and thriller tendencies. It has continued to scare from the sixties to the present day and i am sure it will carry on scaring future generations to come. I am currently making a Horror Film Trailer for A Level Coursework and will try to feature many ideas from this film in my project! A classic horror film that could only be made by someone of Hitchcock's genius.

Review title: A film to influence horror films for generations
Review_body: As one of the most iconic film that Alfred Hitchcock made, the 1960 noir film Psycho was a film that revolved around what had happened to the missing Marion Crane. At her job, Marion decided to steal the money of wealthy customer as an attempt to wipe the debt of her lover, Sam Loomis, in order to marry him. By stealing the money, Marion left her town to keep the money eventually going to the Bates motel and meet Norman Bates. With no information on her sister, Lila Crane and Sam looked for Marion, they too encountered the Bates motel. After seeing the corpse of Mrs.Bates, it is revealed that Norman Bates killed Marion; however, the murder was not done by Norman, but by his mother's persona that he adopted when she died.One of the best component about the movie is the suspense that the movie provided to its audience, which was executed by its film angles, sound track, and composition of the shots. Looking at the first suspenseful moments of the movie, when Marion was leaving town with the money, the angle of the camera switched between her facial expression and the road ahead of. In this segment, the audience can easily tell that the she is worried and panicking about being caught by the law, also by showing the her view we can tell that she is try hard to stay on the road and get further away from her town as she continued to drive in the rain and night. In addition to the camera switching angles between Marion and her perspective, the background music gave the scenes a sense of urgency and was played louder when she was near the police that pulled her over. Making the viewers believe that she was going to be caught. At the Bates motel when Marion encounters Norman, the suspense that the movie can display shined when the two characters alone at diner. Here, Hitchcock had the camera angled in a way to make it seem like Norman is looking down at Marion and the audience, while he discusses the situation about his mother and what he would like to do. Simultaneously, the composition of the scene and music added to the suspense. As viewers see Norman talk, the taxidermy of animals can be seen in the background hanging ominously. Hitchcock deliberately placed the taxidermy of animals, the stuffing of animals, in the background to emphasize Norman's statement about doing potential harm to his mother and death. By talking about how his mother would become cold and lifeless, viewers are able to imagine his mother being dead; in addition, the taxidermies were used to foreshadow that Norman's mother is already dead. Lastly, the low violin tune played when Norman stated his view on institutions gives viewers the idea that he has a spite towards institution, and would potentially do something to Marion because she mentioned it. All of this made viewers in suspense as they think that Norman may attack Marion.Even though the examples that I used to mention the suspense that the movie is able to demonstrate well were from the beginning of the movie, it does not decrease the ability that the movie displays. In order for a movie to be successful, the movie's beginning needs to be executed well to capture viewers like how this movie was able to do with its tune of suspense.Hitchcock knew his components of film well because he made this film a huge success; evident by future films, even recent ones, which make reference to this movie, showing the impact that the movie was able to do on cinema as a whole.

Sorry for the title of the review for possibly tacky, but that's what my experience with the movie says.
I felt like a real crime scene, we have everything in it, a murderer, the victim, the detective, the relatives of the victim, and the cops.
The whole movie is so well built, since nothing is by chance or has any excuse for the events, from the cause of the trauma and second personality of Norman Bates to Marion's reasons for stopping at the Bates Motel.
Speaking more about "Quest" Marion Crane, she's so tense from the moment her boss notices her in the car, right down to the incredible classic murder scene in the bathroom. (It may seem a little obvious that she died in this scene, but I never had taken her spoiler, so for me it was an incredible suspense and tension experience).
Lastly, we have the background of Norman Bates, who I do not know about the others, but I tried a lot to be a detective during the whole movie, so that sheriff scene was spectacular, the plot twist was one of the best I saw.
There are so many more things I would like to talk about, but as it is my first review, I decided not to do much, just what I found necessary, and nothing better than to start with this masterpiece.

In my opinion, Psycho is the greatest film ever made by the greatest director who ever lived. The acting is fantastic (Anthony Perkins' incredible performance as Norman Bates proves he was born to play the part), the soundtrack is flawless and you become enraptured by the film's atmosphere. An important landmark in cinema history, Psycho is truly Hitchcock's masterpiece and a rare example of a perfect film.

The movie caught my eye as we watched it but the movie in itself was outstanding. All the scary scenes,were not jumpscares like they are now. No they were more than that. Alfred Hitchcock used psychology, which i think hints the title. He uses your own imagination against you, getting into your brain and playing with your emotions. He lets your imagination run wild before he shows who was doing all these horrific things. He played the system on this one i think, knowing back then the hays code back then was just terrible. Some parts of the movie he will have you thinking and another part he will have you shaking in your boots. Back to the hays code part of this, you have to admit he did slip through the cracks a bit on this one. The code was extremely strict back then not letting homicide,suicide or even nudity be shown back then. He did not put any in there explicitly letting it be shown. Yet he did let you know what was going on in obvious ways , such as showing blood running down a drain and other things of that nature. This movie was outstanding in my opinion . Every dark vs light aspect was just right showing characters in dark clothing to be evil or crooked, and lighter colored characters to be loving and good. Even the small things like the Mcguffin he got just right in my opinion , you didn't know the importance of it until he wanted you to and that was the crazy thing about this movie, i think every actor and actress played their parts very well. Not letting the plot of the story get tangled and brought off course at all, i think this is one of the best if not the best movie of the early years of films.-Ehvyn Baker
